natural problem: Use synthetic division to divide $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9$ by $x^2-3x+2$ and find the remainder.
natural solution: Since $x^2-3x+2$ factors as $(x-1)(x-2)$ we can divide $x^2-3x+2$ in two steps using synthetic division as follows. First we divide by $x-1$. \[ \begin{array}{rrrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{1} & {1} & -3 & 4 & 11 & -9 \\

\multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 1& -2& 2 & 13 \\ \cline{2-6}  & 1& -2& 2& 13 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{4} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, we find that  $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4$. Then we divide the quotient $x^3-2x^2+2x+13$ by $x-2$.

Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.
\end{aligned}$$The quotient is $x^2+2$ and the remainder is $\boxed{17x-13}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + (17 * x - 13)"
shows  "17 * x - 13 = P x mod Q x"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Use synthetic division to divide $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9$ by $x^2-3x+2$ and find the remainder. The final Answer is 17x-13
 ### Proof
 Since $x^2-3x+2$ factors as $(x-1)(x-2)$ we can divide $x^2-3x+2$ in two steps using synthetic division as follows. First we divide by $x-1$. \[ \begin{array}{rrrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{1} & {1} & -3 & 4 & 11 & -9 \\
 \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 1& -2& 2 & 13 \\ \cline{2-6}  & 1& -2& 2& 13 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{4} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, we find that  $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4$. Then we divide the quotient $x^3-2x^2+2x+13$ by $x-2$.
 \[ \begin{array}{rrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{2} & {1} & -2 & 2 & 13  \\ \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 2& 0& 4  \\ \cline{2-5}  & 1&  0& 2 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{17} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, $x^3-2x^2+2x+13 = (x-2)(x^2+2)+17$.
 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.
 \end{aligned}$$The quotient is $x^2+2$ and the remainder is $\boxed{17x-13}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + (17 * x - 13)"
shows  "17 * x - 13 = P x mod Q x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 3x + 2$, find the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $Q(x)$. The remainder is $17x - 13$.

theorem

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"

and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + 17 * x - 13"
shows  "R x = P x div Q x"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 \[ \begin{array}{rrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{2} & {1} & -2 & 2 & 13  \\ \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 2& 0& 4  \\ \cline{2-5}  & 1&  0& 2 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{17} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, $x^3-2x^2+2x+13 = (x-2)(x^2+2)+17$.
 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + 17 * x - 13"
shows  "R x = P x div Q x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the quotient when a fourth degree polynomial $x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ is divided by a quadratic polynomial $x^2 - 3x + 2$. This quotient is represented by function $R(x)$, which is defined as $R(x) = \frac{P(x)}{Q(x)}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (R x) + 17 * x - 13"
shows  "R x = 17 * x - 13"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (R x) + 17 * x - 13"
shows  "R x = 17 * x - 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given the functions $P(x) = x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 3x + 2$, find $R(x)$ such that $P(x) = Q(x) * R(x) + 17x - 13$. The final answer is $R(x) = 17x - 13$.

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * R x + (17 * x - 13)"
shows  "\<forall> x. 17 * x - 13 = P x mod Q x"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Given two functions $P(x) = x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 3x + 2$, if $P(x)$ equals to $Q(x)$ times another function $R(x)$ plus $(17x - 13)$, then the remainder of $P(x)$ divided by $Q(x)$ is always $(17x - 13)$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 17 * x - 13"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Use synthetic division to divide $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9$ by $x^2-3x+2$ and find the remainder. The final Answer is 17x-13

 Since $x^2-3x+2$ factors as $(x-1)(x-2)$ we can divide $x^2-3x+2$ in two steps using synthetic division as follows. First we divide by $x-1$. \[ \begin{array}{rrrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{1} & {1} & -3 & 4 & 11 & -9 \\

 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 17 * x - 13"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. P x = Q x * (R x) + (17 * x - 13)"
shows  "R x = 17 * x - 13"

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + remainder"
shows  "remainder = 17 * x - 13"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Use synthetic division to divide $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9$ by $x^2-3x+2$ and find the remainder. The final Answer is 17x-13
 ### Proof
 Since $x^2-3x+2$ factors as $(x-1)(x-2)$ we can divide $x^2-3x+2$ in two steps using synthetic division as follows. First we divide by $x-1$. \[ \begin{array}{rrrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{1} & {1} & -3 & 4 & 11 & -9 \\
 \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 1& -2& 2 & 13 \\ \cline{2-6}  & 1& -2& 2& 13 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{4} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, we find that  $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4$. Then we divide the quotient $x^3-2x^2+2x+13$ by $x-2$.
 \[ \begin{array}{rrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{2} & {1} & -2 & 2 & 13  \\ \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 2& 0& 4  \\ \cline{2-5}  & 1&  0& 2 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{17} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, $x^3-2x^2+2x+13 = (x-2)(x^2+2)+17$.
 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.
 \end{aligned}$$The quotient is $x^2+2$ and the remainder is $\boxed{17x-13}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3 * x powr 3 + 4 * x powr 2 + 11 * x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3 * x + 2"
and h2 : "P x = Q x * R x + remainder"
shows  "remainder = 17 * x - 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given that $P(x) = x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ and $Q(x) = x^2 - 3x + 2$, find the remainder when $P(x)$ is divided by $Q(x)$. The remainder is $17x - 13$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3*x powr 3 + 4*x powr 2 + 11*x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3*x + 2"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 17*x - 13"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Use synthetic division to divide $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9$ by $x^2-3x+2$ and find the remainder. The final Answer is 17x-13
 ### Proof
 Since $x^2-3x+2$ factors as $(x-1)(x-2)$ we can divide $x^2-3x+2$ in two steps using synthetic division as follows. First we divide by $x-1$. \[ \begin{array}{rrrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{1} & {1} & -3 & 4 & 11 & -9 \\
 \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 1& -2& 2 & 13 \\ \cline{2-6}  & 1& -2& 2& 13 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{4} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, we find that  $x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4$. Then we divide the quotient $x^3-2x^2+2x+13$ by $x-2$.
 \[ \begin{array}{rrrrr} \multicolumn{1}{r|}{2} & {1} & -2 & 2 & 13  \\ \multicolumn{1}{r|}{} & & 2& 0& 4  \\ \cline{2-5}  & 1&  0& 2 & \multicolumn{1}{|r}{17} \\ \end{array} \]Thus, $x^3-2x^2+2x+13 = (x-2)(x^2+2)+17$.
 Substituting this expression into our first equation gives $$\begin{aligned} x^4-3x^3+4x^2+11x-9&=(x-1)(x^3-2x^2+2x+13)+4 \\ &=(x-1)[(x-2)(x^2+2)+17]+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17(x-1)+4 \\ &=(x-1)(x-2)(x^2+2)+17x-13.
 \end{aligned}$$The quotient is $x^2+2$ and the remainder is $\boxed{17x-13}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and P Q R :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. P x = x powr 4 - 3*x powr 3 + 4*x powr 2 + 11*x - 9"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. Q x = x powr 2 - 3*x + 2"
and h2 : "P x mod Q x = R x"
shows  "R x = 17*x - 13"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the remainder when the polynomial $x^4 - 3x^3 + 4x^2 + 11x - 9$ is divided by the polynomial $x^2 - 3x + 2$. The remainder is a polynomial of the form $17x - 13$.
